questions.question: A deterioration in lakes and forests in northern Europe was first noticed in [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "the late 1970s". Check the opening of paragraph A.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. Review the passage to find the correct answer.

1.correct: Excellent! Paragraph A begins "In the late 1970s, people in northern Europe were observing a change in the lakes and forests."
1.incorrect: The correct answer is "the late 1970s". Paragraph A states when the changes were first observed.
1.no_answer: The correct answer is "the late 1970s". Check the opening of paragraph A.

questions.question: Pollution in rain is a result of [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "sulphuric and nitric acids". Paragraph A explains what causes acid rain.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. Review the passage to find the correct answer.

1.correct: Correct! Paragraph A states acid rain is "pollutants in rain, snow, hail and fog caused by sulphuric and nitric acids."
1.incorrect: The correct answer is "sulphuric and nitric acids". Paragraph A identifies these as the cause of pollution in rain.
1.no_answer: The correct answer is "sulphuric and nitric acids". Paragraph A explains what causes acid rain.

questions.question: Nearly half of manmade sources of acid rain are due to [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "transportation sources". Paragraph B breaks down sources of manmade acid rain.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. Review the passage to find the correct answer.

1.correct: Well done! Paragraph B states "transportation sources account for 40%" - nearly half of the manmade sources listed.
1.incorrect: The correct answer is "transportation sources". Paragraph B shows transportation accounts for 40% of manmade acid rain.
1.no_answer: The correct answer is "transportation sources". Paragraph B breaks down sources of manmade acid rain.

questions.question: Some animals have declined in number by over 50% because of scarcer [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "fish". Paragraph D discusses the food chain impact of acid rain.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. Review the passage to find the correct answer.

1.correct: Excellent! Paragraph D explains "animals that rely on fish as a food source" and mentions "American otter have had their numbers reduced by over half."
1.incorrect: The correct answer is "fish". Paragraph D connects declining fish populations to animal population decreases.
1.no_answer: The correct answer is "fish". Paragraph D discusses the food chain impact of acid rain.

questions.question: Land used for farming is becoming [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "less productive". Paragraph D discusses agricultural impacts.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. Review the passage to find the correct answer.

1.correct: Correct! Paragraph D states acid rain is "destroying the effectiveness of farmland, making it significantly less productive."
1.incorrect: The correct answer is "less productive". Paragraph D describes how acid rain reduces farmland productivity.
1.no_answer: The correct answer is "less productive". Paragraph D discusses agricultural impacts.

questions.question: Urban household water supplies are contaminated by [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "toxic metals". Paragraph E discusses contamination of water supplies.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. Review the passage to find the correct answer.

1.correct: Well done! Paragraph E states "the drinking water is laced with toxic metals freed from metal pipes by the acidity."
1.incorrect: The correct answer is "toxic metals". Paragraph E explains how acidity releases toxic metals from pipes into drinking water.
1.no_answer: The correct answer is "toxic metals". Paragraph E discusses contamination of water supplies.

questions.question: Air pollution is travelling further as it is disgorged through [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "tall chimneys". Paragraph F discusses how pollution dispersal has changed.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. Review the passage to find the correct answer.

1.correct: Excellent! Paragraph F states pollution "can be transported thousands of kilometres due to the introduction of tall chimneys dispersing pollutants high into the atmosphere."
1.incorrect: The correct answer is "tall chimneys". Paragraph F explains that tall chimneys allow pollution to travel much farther.
1.no_answer: The correct answer is "tall chimneys". Paragraph F discusses how pollution dispersal has changed.

questions.question: Legislation passed in the 1980s and the 1990s was a response to [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "transboundary pollution". Paragraph G explains what prompted international legislation.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. Review the passage to find the correct answer.

1.correct: Correct! Paragraph G states "Transboundary pollution, the spread of acid rain across political and international borders, has prompted a number of international responses. International legislation during the 1980s and 1990s..."

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 1
reading_texts.content:
Masley Pets Sale

Come and see Eric and the team at Masley Pets to get a bargain! All pets are currently on sale with up to 20% off*.

Excludes fish.

Our knowledgeable staff will be able to advise you on which pet would suit your requirements best and how to keep your pet fit and healthy. Kane is our resident fish expert and Laura will tell you all you need to know about any of our four-legged friends.

We currently have the following in stock:

Dogs Cocker Spaniels – 3 – £700 German Shepherd – 1 – £750 Poodle – 3 – £650

Cats Persian – 2 – £500 Siamese – 1 – £450 Moggie – 2 – £90

Fish Angel Fish – 40+ – £30 Firemouth – 12 – £20 Goldfish – 20 – £8

Birds
Budgie – OUT OF STOCK – £25
Canary – 6 – £25
Finch – 12 – £22
Lovebird – 4 – £28

Small animals
Mouse – 5 – £7
Guinea pigs – 2 – £20
Hamsters – 1 – £7.50
Rats – 3 – £8.50

We also have a wide range of accessories in stock.

Questions 1–6

[Section 1
This is an open question set.
Question type: Short answer.
There are 6 questions (1–6).
Answers must use NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS from the passage.]

What pets are not included in the sale? Answer: fish

What pet is currently unavailable? Answer: budgie

What is the most expensive dog? Answer: German Shepherd

Apart from pets, what else can you buy at Masley Pets? Answer: accessories

Who is the best person to ask about cats? Answer: Laura

What is the cheapest pet in the shop? Answer: mouse

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 2
reading_texts.content:
Workplace Harassment

Workplace harassment may involve unfair criticism in public, withholding resources such as information or equipment, or encouraging co-workers to participate in harassment.

If you feel harassed:

Keep records of incidents, including dates, locations and witnesses.

Talk to your manager, unless they are involved, in which case approach senior management in writing.

Avoid retaliation, as it weakens your case.

Do not resign prematurely. Harassment often continues with future staff if unreported.

Questions 13–16

[Section 2
This is an open question set.
Question type: Summary completion.
There are 4 questions (13–16).
Answers must use NO MORE THAN ONE WORD from the text.]

Feelings of unfair ______ from workmates or superiors may indicate harassment.
Answer: pressure

Harassment may involve criticism in ______. Answer: public

Work may be disrupted by lack of proper ______. Answer: resources

Harassment may be supported by ______. Answer: co-workers

Questions 17–21

[Section 2
This is an open question set.
Question type: Short answer.
There are 5 questions (17–21).
Answers must use NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS from the text.]

Why should records be kept? Answer: evidence / invaluable evidence

Who should be contacted if the manager is responsible?
Answer: senior management

What action should employees avoid? Answer: retaliate

What should employees avoid doing prematurely? Answer: quit

Harassers gain increased ______ if victims leave. Answer: confidence

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 3
reading_texts.content:
A: In [Q32][Q33]the late 1970s, people in northern Europe were observing a change in the lakes and forests around them. Areas once famous for the quality and quantity of their fish began to decline, and areas of once-green forest were dying. The phenomenon they witnessed was acid rain – pollutants in rain, snow, hail and fog caused by [Q34]sulphuric and nitric acids.

B: [Q26]The principal chemicals that cause these acids are sulphur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen, both by-products of burning fossil fuels (coal, oil and gas). A percentage of acid rain is natural, from volcanoes, forest fires and biological decay, but the majority is unsurprisingly manmade. Of this, [Q35]transportation sources account for 40%; power plants 30%; industrial sources 25%; and commercial institutions and residues 5%. What makes these figures particularly disturbing is that since the 1970s, nitrogen oxide emissions have tripled. Each year the global atmosphere is polluted with 20 billion tons of carbon dioxide, 130 million tons of sulphur dioxide, more than three million tons of toxic metals, and a wealth of synthetic organic compounds, many of which are proven causes of cancer, genetic mutations and birth defects.

C: [Q27]For natural causes of acid rain, nature has provided a filter. Naturally occurring substances such as limestone or other antacids can neutralise this acid rain before it enters the water cycle, thereby protecting it. However, areas with a predominantly quartzite- or granite-based geology and little top soil have no such effect, and the basic environment shifts from an alkaline to an acidic one. Recycled and intensified through the water table, acid rain has reached such a degree in some parts of the world that rainfall is now 40 times more acidic than normal – the same acidic classification as vinegar.

D: [Q28]Environmentally, the impact is devastating. Lakes and the life they support are dying, unable to withstand such a battering. This has a direct effect on the animals that rely on [Q36]fish as a food source. Certain species of American otter have had their numbers reduced by over half in the last 20 years, for example. Yet this is not the only effect. Nitrogen oxides, the principal reagent in acid rain, react with other pollutants to produce ozone, a major air pollutant responsible for destroying the effectiveness of farmland, making it significantly [Q37]less productive. With scientists working on producing ever bigger and longer lasting genetically modified foods, some farmers are reporting abnormally low yields. Tomatoes grow to only half their full weight and the leaves, stalks and roots of other crops never reach full maturity.

E: [Q29]Naturally it rains on cities too, eating away stone monuments and concrete structures, and corroding the pipes which channel the water away to the lakes where the cycle is repeated. Paint exposed to rain is not lasting as long due to the pollution in the atmosphere speeding up the corrosion process. In some communities the drinking water is laced with [Q38]toxic metals freed from metal pipes by the acidity. After any period of non-use, we are encouraged to run taps for at least 60 seconds to flush any excess debris, as increased concentrations of metals in plumbing such as lead, copper and zinc result in adverse health effects. As if urban skies were not already grey enough, typical visibility has declined from ten to four miles, in many American cities, as acid rain turns into smog. Also, now there are indicators that the components of acid rain are a health risk, linked to human respiratory disease.

F: [Q30]Acid rain itself is not an entirely new phenomenon. In the nineteenth century, acid rain fell both in towns and cities. What is new, and of great concern, is that it can be transported thousands of kilometres due to the introduction of [Q39]tall chimneys dispersing pollutants high into the atmosphere, allowing strong wind currents to blow the acid rain hundreds of miles from its source. Thus the areas where acid rain falls are not necessarily the areas where the pollution comes from. Pollution from industrial areas of England are damaging forests in Scotland and Scandinavia. Acids from the Midwest United States are blown into northwest Canada. More and more regions are beginning to be affected, and given that 13 of the world's most polluted cities are in neighbouring Asia, countries like Australia and New Zealand are increasingly under threat.

G: [Q31][Q40]Transboundary pollution, the spread of acid rain across political and international borders, has prompted a number of international responses. International legislation during the 1980s and 1990s has led to reductions in sulphur dioxide emissions in many countries but reductions in emissions of nitrogen oxides have been much less, leading to the conclusion that without a cooperative global effort, the problem of acid rain will not simply blow away.
